title: 108_hr4139
content: The Act titled "State Business Law Conformity Act of 2004" references general partners. The Act "State Business Law Conformity Act of 2004" pertains to exclusion of certain active businesses from at-risk rules, payments to retiring partners, and foreign currency transactions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The interest of a partner in a partnership shall not fail to meet ownership requirements if the partner is not limited in participation in the management or activity of the qualified fund. Special Valuation Rules for Generation-Skipping Tax: Amendment made to section 2701(b)(2)(B) of the Code regarding partnerships, specifically limited partnerships. The tax matters partner of a partnership is either the partner designated in regulations or the partner with the largest profits interest at the end of the taxable year. The tax matters partner of a partnership is selected either by designation in regulations or based on having the largest profits interest at the end of the taxable year. If no partner is designated or it is impracticable to apply the designation, the Secretary will select the tax matters partner and notify all partners accordingly. The tax matters partner of a partnership cannot be limited in management or activity participation. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2004. SEC. 3. REFERENCES TO LIMITED PARTNERS. Limited Entrepreneur definition under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude limited partners. Conforming amendments are made to related sections in the Code. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to exclude limited partners from the Limited Entrepreneur definition and related sections. This includes changes to subsection (e)(3)(C) and (e)(4)(A)(i), as well as section 1258(d)(5)(C) and subsection (h) of section 469. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to exclude limited partners from the Limited Entrepreneur definition and related sections. This includes changes to subsection (e)(3)(C) and (e)(4)(A)(i), as well as section 1258(d)(5)(C) and subsection (h) of section 469. Additionally, specific paragraphs and subparagraphs are amended within the Code to adjust passive loss limitations. The amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exclude limited partners from the Limited Entrepreneur definition and related sections. This includes adjustments to passive loss limitations for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004. SEC. 4. Partnership income attributable to capital excluded from net earnings from self-employment. The distributive share of net income of a partner attributable to capital is excluded. Partnership income attributable to capital includes amounts exceeding reasonable compensation for services and a reasonable rate of return on unreturned capital. The partner's return on unreturned capital is determined at the beginning of the taxable year. Unreturned capital is the excess of money and fair market value contributed by the partner over distributed amounts, adjusted for the partner's share of reportable items. The partner's unreturned capital is adjusted under section 754 if an election is made, with a reasonable rate of return set at 150 percent of the highest applicable Federal rate. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations for this subsection. The amendments made by this section will be effective. Effective Date: The amendments made by this section will apply to services performed in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF ABILITY TO ELECT LARGE PARTNERSHIP REPORTING RULES. The election under section 775(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 shall not be made after December 31, 2004, and this amendment applies to partnership taxable years starting after that date.
